text:
Bodega Catena Zapata is one of the most prestigious
winemakers in Argentina and in the world.

How do you, yourself, describe 
the Bodega Catena Zapata?

Well, we are the oldest family winery
in Argentina, still in family hands.

And I'm really proud of that
because I don't think it's very easy

to maintain a family business for that
long and to have pioneered so many things.

You know, starting with my great
grandfather who came from Italy.

He was 18 years old with nothing.
He set up his winery,
planting his first vines in 1902.

And then my grandfather
expanded the business, planted vineyards,

and then my father, I think, is really
the key figure who decided

to make Argentine wines that could compete
with the best of the world,

which was very radical,
you know, in the early nineties.

You had Chile that had conquered the world
with their inexpensive wines.

And most of Argentina was thinking of
going in the same direction.

And my father was inspired actually
by the Napa Valley, by Robert Mondavi,

to say, "Hey, why don't I go against
the French, who are the top in wine?"
And that was so radical and so daring.
And it's still what drives me

is to make Argentine wines
that can stand with the best of the world.

And we can, and we have,
because we have all these 100 point wines.
So, you know,

to answer your question,
what is Bodega Catena Zapata?

I think Bodega Catena Zapata 
is a family winery that has managed
to continue to be pioneering,
to do things that nobody would expect

a winery in Argentina
to do through multiple generations.

And now, it remains to be seen
if I can keep this up
with the next generations to come.
